line_1: With equal gravity peruse
line_2: The dictates of the Parson's Muse.

line_1: When tender virgins shall your page peruse,
line_2: Their tear-dimm'd eyes will all their lustre lose;

line_1: O Madam, deign with candour to peruse
line_2: A rustic lay, presented by the Muse.

line_1: Curious each pamphlet I peruse,
line_2: And sip my coffee o'er the news.

line_1: His lady's worth, his daughter's we peruse,
line_2: And find his grandsons all as rich as Jews:

line_1: In vain I oft harmonious lines peruse,
line_2: And seek for aid from POPE'S and PRIOR'S Muse;

line_1: Those who ne'er deign'd their Bible to peruse,
line_2: Would think it hard to be denied their News;

line_1: While She her Mother's Letter did peruse,
line_2: Her lovely face, he with attention views:

line_1: With her the Labours of the Wise peruse;
line_2: Hither, ye Nymphs, attend the leading Muse,

line_1: Or Post-boy, or Gazette peruse,
line_2: So have I seen a man of news

line_1: SIR, I your letter did peruse;
line_2: So elegant the style you use,

line_1: SIR, I your letter did peruse;
line_2: Abash'd, confounded I did muse

line_1: SIR, I your letter did peruse;
line_2: Great wit and learning you diffuse

line_1: Who Cheny's records for Rapin peruse.
line_2: Unskill'd in Albion's past and present views,

line_1: This is a sight for pity to peruse
line_2: 'Till she resemble faintly what she views,

line_1: And if some lucky thought, while you peruse,
line_2: In gratitude she'll thank th' indulgent Muse,

line_1: May safely every page peruse,
line_2: Nor be offended with the Muse;

line_1: Still with It self compar'd, his Text peruse;
line_2: And let your Comment be the Mantuan Muse.

line_1: In the next place, his feet peruse,
line_2: Wings grow again from both his shoes

line_1: Nor will we thanklessly peruse
line_2: The beauties of his native muse,

line_1: So long the brighest eye shall oft peruse
line_2: The useful lines of my instructive Muse;
